member.summary: Size of file content, in bytes

member.summary: Handle to the filesystem that this file comes from

member.name: P:SleuthKit.FileSystemEntry.Address
member.summary: The filesystem identifier, or inode of this file

member.summary: Number of entries in this directory

member.name: T:SleuthKit.DiskImage
member.summary: An object encapsulating the SleuthKit disk image functions. See http://www.sleuthkit.org/sleuthkit/docs/api-docs/imgpage.html for more info.

member.name: T:SleuthKit.IContent
member.summary: An item that has content. Size is provided separately because sometimes getting a stream to content is expensive, and it is nice to provide the stream length without opening the stream. It is worth noting, however, that sometimes IContent implementations will specify a Size that is not consistent with the amount of bytes you can read from the Stream returned by OpenRead. Sometimes we don't know that content is unavailable until the caller is reading it, so take the Size with a grain of salt.

member.name: M:SleuthKit.IContent.OpenRead
member.summary: Opens the content for reading. Since this library is designed for reading disk images, there isn't going to be an OpenWrite.

member.name: P:SleuthKit.IContent.Size
member.summary: The length of the content, in bytes. See remarks for the IContent interface for more information about this property. Basically it is here so that you don't need to call OpenRead just to get the stream length.

member.name: M:SleuthKit.DiskImage.Init(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.IO.FileInfo})
member.summary: Initializes sleuthkit with the specified image files (calls tsk_img_open_* methods)

member.name: M:SleuthKit.DiskImage.ToString
member.summary: A little diagnostic info about the disk image

member.name: M:SleuthKit.DiskImage.ReadBytes(System.Int64,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: allows reading specified portions of the disk image

member.name: M:SleuthKit.DiskImage.OpenRead
member.summary: Returns a stream to the disk image contents. Particularly useful if you are reading something other than a dd image.

member.name: M:SleuthKit.DiskImage.OpenFileSystem(SleuthKit.FileSystemType,System.Int64)
member.summary: Opens a filesystem - for images with no partition table, i.e. volume images, or most SD cards and thumb drives that are formatted .

member.name: M:SleuthKit.DiskImage.GetFileSystems
member.summary: Returns an enumeration of all filesystems on the disk image. Here for convenience when writing LINQ queries.

member.name: P:SleuthKit.DiskImage.Size
member.summary: the size of this disk image, in bytes

member.name: P:SleuthKit.DiskImage.SectorSize
member.summary: the size of a sector on this disk image, in bytes

member.summary: TSK_FS_META_FLAG_ORPHAN, Return only metadata structures that have no file name pointing to the (inode_walk flag only)

member.summary: TSK_FS_META_ATTR_STUDIED, The data in the attributes are for this file

member.summary: TSK_FS_META_ATTR_ERROR, The attributes for this file could not be loaded

member.summary: TSK_FS_META_TYPE_VIRT, "Virtual File" created by TSK for file system areas

member.summary: Managed version of TSK_FS_META_MODE_ENUM. The following describe the file permissions

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FilesystemInfoFlag.HasSequenceNumbers
member.summary: TSK_FS_INFO_FLAG_HAVE_SEQ, File system has sequence numbers in the inode addresses.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FilesystemInfoFlag.HasNanoSec
member.summary: TSK_FS_INFO_FLAG_HAVE_NANOSEC, Nano second field in times will be set.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileReadFlag.Slack
member.summary: TSK_FS_FILE_READ_FLAG_SLACK, Allow read access into slack space

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileReadFlag.NoID
member.summary: TSK_FS_FILE_READ_FLAG_NOID , Ignore the Id argument given in the API (use only the type)

member.name: T:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags
member.summary: Flags that are used in TSK_FS_BLOCK and in callback of file_walk. Note that some of these are dependent. A block can be either TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_ALLOC or TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_UNALLOC. It can be one of TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_RAW, TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_BAD, TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_RES, TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_SPARSE, or TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_COMP. Note that some of these are set only by file_walk because they are file-level details, such as compression and sparse.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Unused
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_UNUSED, Used to show that TSK_FS_BLOCK structure has no data in it

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Allocated
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_ALLOC, Block is allocated (and not TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_UNALLOC)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Unallocated
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_UNALLOC, Block is unallocated (and not TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_ALLOC)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Content
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_CONT, Block (could) contain file content (and not TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_META)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Metadata
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_META, Block (could) contain file system metadata (and not TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_CONT)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Bad
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_BAD, Block has been marked as bad by the file system

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Raw
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_RAW, The data has been read raw from the disk (and not COMP or SPARSE)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Sparse
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_SPARSE, The data passed in the file_walk calback was stored as sparse (all zeros) (and not RAW or COMP)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.Compressed
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_COMP, The data passed in the file_walk callback was stored in a compressed form (and not RAW or SPARSE)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.NTFSResident
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_RES , The data passed in the file_walk callback is from an NTFS resident file

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileSystemBlockFlags.FlagAonly
member.summary: TSK_FS_BLOCK_FLAG_AONLY, TSK_FS_BLOCK has no content (it could be non-empty, but should be ignored), but the flags and such are accurate

member.name: T:SleuthKit.FileWalkFlag
member.summary: Flags used by tsk_fs_file_walk to determine when the callback function should be used.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileWalkFlag.Slack
member.summary: Include the file's slack space in the callback.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileWalkFlag.NoId
member.summary: Ignore the Id argument given in the API (use only the type).

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileWalkFlag.AOnly
member.summary: Provide callback with only addresses and no file content.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.FileWalkFlag.NoSparse
member.summary: Do not include sparse blocks in the callback.

member.name: T:SleuthKit.Endianness
member.summary: Endian .. little or big .. or middle!
member.remarks: The term big-endian originally comes from Jonathan Swift's satirical novel Gulliverâ€™s Travels by way of Danny Cohen in 1980. In 1726, Swift described tensions in Lilliput and Blefuscu: whereas royal edict in Lilliput requires cracking open one's soft-boiled egg at the small end, inhabitants of the rival kingdom of Blefuscu crack theirs at the big end (giving them the moniker Big-endians). The terms little-endian and endianness have a similar intent. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endianness

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Endianness.Little
member.summary: TSK_LIT_ENDIAN, Data is in little endian

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Endianness.Big
member.summary: TSK_BIG_ENDIAN, Data is in big endian

member.summary: TSK_IMG_TYPE_AFF_ANY, Any format supported by AFFLIB (including beta ones)

member.summary: TSK_VS_PART_FLAG_ALLOC, Sectors are allocated to a volume in the volume system

member.summary: TSK_VS_PART_FLAG_UNALLOC, Sectors are not allocated to a volume

member.name: F:SleuthKit.VolumeFlags.Metadata

member.name: F:SleuthKit.VolumeFlags.All
member.summary: TSK_VS_PART_FLAG_ALL, Show all sectors in the walk.

member.summary: Contains resident data (i.e. in a small buffer)

Pointer that will be passed to callback.

member.summary: ctor for filesystem that comes from within a volume

member.returns: Whether the operation is successful or not.

member.summary: tag, can be used to validate that we have the right kind of struct. a magic header for the struct, essentially.

member.summary: Flags for this file for its allocation status etc.

member.summary: Address of the meta data structure for this file

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.nlink
member.summary: link count (number of file names pointing to this)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.size
member.summary: file size (in bytes) - yes this is a signed 64-bit integer, despite it being unsigned in sleuthkit (?). It is easier this way.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.mtime
member.summary: last file content modification time (stored in number of seconds since Jan 1, 1970 UTC)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.mtime_nano
member.summary: nano-second resolution in addition to m_time

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.atime
member.summary: last file content accessed time (stored in number of seconds since Jan 1, 1970 UTC)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.atime_nano
member.summary: nano-second resolution in addition to a_time

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.ctime
member.summary: last file / metadata status change time (stored in number of seconds since Jan 1, 1970 UTC)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.ctime_nano
member.summary: nano-second resolution in addition to c_time

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.crtime
member.summary: Created time (stored in number of seconds since Jan 1, 1970 UTC)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.crtime_nano
member.summary: nano-second resolution in addition to cr_time

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.content_ptr
member.summary: Pointer to file system specific data that is used to store references to file content

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.seq
member.summary: Sequence number for file (NTFS only, is incremented when entry is reallocated)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.attr_ptr
member.summary: Contains run data on the file content (specific locations where content is stored). Check attr_state to determine if data in here is valid because not all file systems load this data when a file is loaded. It may not be loaded until needed by one of the APIs. Most file systems will have only one attribute, but NTFS will have several.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.attr_state
member.summary: State of the data in the TSK_FS_META::attr structure

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.name2
member.summary: Name of file stored in metadata (FAT and NTFS Only)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.link
member.summary: Name of target file if this is a symbolic link

member.name: P:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.AppearsValid
member.summary: validates the tag contains the proper constant

member.name: P:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.MTime
member.summary: Modified time in unix epoch ticks

member.name: P:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.ATime
member.summary: Access time in unix epoch ticks

member.name: P:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.CTime
member.summary: Metadata change time in unix epoch ticks

member.name: P:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_META.CRTime
member.summary: Kreayshawn time in unix epoch ticks

member.name: T:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_FILE
member.summary: represents TSK_FS_FILE. Generic structure used to refer to files in the file system. A file will typically have a name and metadata. This structure holds that type of information. When deleted files are being processed, this structure may have the name defined but not metadata because it no longer exists.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_FILE.tag
member.summary: tag, can be used to validate that we have the right kind of struct. a magic header for the struct, essentially.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_FILE.ptr_filename
member.summary: pointer to filename struct - or null if file was opened using metadata address

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_FILE.ptr_meta
member.summary: Pointer to metadata of file (or NULL if name has invalid metadata address)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_FILE.ptr_fsinfo
member.summary: Pointer to file system that the file is located in.

member.name: P:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_FILE.AppearsValid
member.summary: validates the tag contains the proper constant

member.name: P:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_BLOCK.AppearsValid
member.summary: validates the tag contains the proper constant

member.summary: tag, can be used to validate that we have the right kind of struct. a magic header for the struct, essentially.

member.name: T:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME
member.summary: TSK_FS_NAME Generic structure to store the file name information that is stored in a directory. Most file systems seperate the file name from the metadata, but some do not (such as FAT). This structure contains the name and address of the metadata.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.tag
member.summary: tag, can be used to validate that we have the right kind of struct. a magic header for the struct, essentially.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.ptr_name
member.summary: The name of the file (in UTF-8)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.name_size
member.summary: The number of bytes allocated to name

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.ptr_short_name
member.summary: The short name of the file or null (in UTF-8)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.short_name_size
member.summary: The number of bytes allocated to shrt_name

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.meta_addr
member.summary: Address of the metadata structure that the name points to.

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.meta_seq
member.summary: Sequence number for metadata structure (NTFS only)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.par_addr
member.summary: Metadata address of parent directory (equal to meta_addr if this entry is for root directory).

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.par_seq
member.summary: Sequence number for parent directory (NTFS only)

member.name: F:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.flags
member.summary: Flags that describe allocation status etc.

member.name: M:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.GetName
member.summary: returns the long name or short name, depending on whats available.

member.name: M:SleuthKit.Structs.TSK_FS_NAME.ToString
member.summary: Prints out the name, long name first, if it is null then it tries short name.

member.summary: validates the tag contains the proper constant

member.summary: TSK_VS_PART_INFO structure is used to describe each volume. This structure has fields for the volume starting offset (relative to the start of the disk image), length, and type.
